text: oh good! Was going to ask if we’d heard from him
Yeah. Looks like he went ahead and responded to Megan and the test plan directly, but given the engagement and the content of the note, I think it sounds like a green light
<@U0HP6TFNX> thoughts?
SOW seems good to me, pending what Gidge’s last note was back.
Great! I’ll forward to you
Btw, related, this is a great podcast about complicated back-end systems with deceptively simple UIs :slightly_smiling_face: <https://soundcloud.com/a16z/complexity>

attachments.title: a16z Podcast: It's Complicated by a16z
attachments.text:
For better or worse, most of the computing systems that run much of our lives (whether invisibly or visibly) have become increasingly complex -- they're not fully engineered; they're almost grown. And with that we enter a brave new world of "biological" (as opposed to a more "physics") mindset applied to computing. It's more like evolution, horns and all.

This isn't just abstract or backend-only stuff. Complex system design affects everything from datacenters and SaaS to word processors and cars, touching human lives in very tangible ways. So how do you solve problems in such systems? How do you even begin to understand "the system" in the first place? And is there anything out there yet that lets us test and verify the output of these systems? (Inquiring minds want to know!) 

All this and more in this episode of the a16z Podcast, a riff on the theme of "complicated" with complexity scientist Samuel Arbesman and author of the new book Overcomplicated. Also joining the conversation (with Sonal Chokshi) are a16z board partner Steven Sinofsky and research and deal team head Frank Chen.

image: brewbooks / Flickr
attachments.fallback: SoundCloud Audio: Link: a16z Podcast: It's Complicated by a16z

text: His notes mostly sounded minor, not really changing the plan. The biggest thing, which gives me pause, was about the post-workshop website being out of scope of the test
We'll need to come up with some sort of takeaway promise, in order to motivate people to use the device
right
We can do a prototype version of some sort, but I don't think we can test device photos effectively if they go into a black hole
where’s he sayign this stuff? I think i’m missing some threads or something
He's commenting on the google sheet with the test plan details
but i agree entirely Megan that we need them to go somewhere
What about just doing the hero video with human glue. i.e. Manually curating and inputting photos into the look back video
we already have a movie template. we’ll want to refine design later on, but should be sufficient for now
My sense is that we need something in addition to a video. Even if it's access to a google drive with the photos
Yeah, I think that could work too
wonder if we could have the most simple webpage that pulls photos from that drive
or something like that
Something along the lines of, all the photos you have taken will be available to you after the day in a drive. Plus, there’s somethign special at the end
just a front end that pulls content from somewhere
That does’t sound too difficult either
to get CLOSE to end goal without worrying too much about the mechanics of interaction or polished design
because yeah - i agree it’s really a huge part of the story
Yep. Not ideal at all, considering how much of the concept hinges on the right presentation of the EOD data. However, doesn’t seem like a blocker.. Just something we’ll need to navigate.

yep. there are probably good out of the box options for photo sharing. If we’re testing the inclusion of annotations, that might need some thought, but I bet we can find a lightweight way to include that text

Yep! And, I actually think it makes for a really interesting challenge. There’s reasonably high chance that EventGuide and EventHub don’t lend themselves to the level of customization we want. If that’s the case, we’ll need to figure out whether without our desired customization the entire concept is DOA or whether their is another option that can be coupled with EventHub
but is sounds like, however we prototype this or whatever the capabilities of eventguide are, this can’t be considered “out of scope” for us
Forcing us to come up with an alternative, should give us the right data to know whether EventHub customization is a make or break variable
Good point Sarah. I think Gidge is saying that because of all the EventGuide stuff, but in the SOW, I’ll definitely call out “a method for presenting photos taken in workshop”
sure and we can save the more gnarly details of integrating with eventguide for when we know more
Yep. Again, not ideal. But neither would testing a mock UI that we aren’t able to implement :confused:
<@U0HP6TFNX> how many days do you feel you’ll need at each location. 3?
Sorry - just seeing this now (meetings)
agreed with all this needs to be in scope
question for the group:
is it better for us to a find a system that is basic but dynamic, or better to say “were going to test this over three workshops” and just hand code a UI we want people to see?
for testing purposes, I think either way is fine. for budget purposes, maybe we need to make a call

<@U0B9N0HF0> I budgeted 8 total on site days for admins and guests combined. depends on recruiting and how dense we can get the schedule and if we can combine trips, but our plan was to coach google on any additional sessions needed.
Ok cool. Yeah, I was thinking 3 ppl x 3 days, 2 nights x 2 (SBO and NY)?
um, I might need to see that broken down, I’m not following the math
but my budget was 8 days, 2 people, so 16 uncorked days total
This gives us the flexibility for 1 BL session + set-up process + take-away interviews
so long as we’re good with budget. here’s how I broke it down <https://docs.google.com/a/uncorkedstudios.com/spreadsheets/d/1NkzOrZ6MNj4YsX6BTwyslxAKUc_WQRWdw_ojQ_HgT3c/edit?usp=sharing>

text: Ok thanks. Yeah, I was thinking more travel budget, but that’s a great point. Probably will need to be 2 ppl x 3 days (2 nights) x 2 locations = 6 Uncorked Days. That would be you and Sarah. Then either Justin and I could come for one of the sessions
yeah, I didn’t include any travel expenses on this spreadsheet, just an hours breakdown. but it was pretty close to our 500 hour cap on the test plan
as a reminder, this was just the test plan, so producer/creative direction/prototyping hours need to be included in the mix
Cool. Yep, It’s a bit difficult to do the others because we want to A.) protect the integrity of the test plan B.) have to back into the 100k number, but I’ll be working to find the right mix
I have travel at approx. 7k with the revised staffing plan, but that’s Google $$$
ok, let me know if you want to get together and play with the pieces we could move around on the budget
Sounds good! I think that’d be a good idea. Put something on your calendar for tmrw?
sure, my day is pretty open
<@U0B9N0HF0> can you send <@U02918BKW> and i the SOW for 100K BLMobile via email when you get a chance?

So - 1) sorry I've been absent from this today. 2) as long as we're cool on the post-workshop site being in-scope I'm fine saving the implementation details for later. But did want to double check that we are including that.
<@U0260V4K1> we are not including that. I did insert language around: "A method for delivering photos and content post-workshop"
Not being sarcastic but do we have something in mind that does that that's not a website?
